title: Standard English Conventions Fundamentals
learning_objectives: Avoid traps that mimic speech patterns but break rules

content.title: Common Pitfalls
content.explanation: Trap choices often mimic how people speak casually but ignore grammar rules.
content.example: Run-ons with 'and' or missing commas after introductory phrases are frequent traps.

content.title: 5-Step Approach
steps: Step 1: Spot the grammar focus — boundary, verb, pronoun, punctuation.
Step 2: Predict the correction before reading choices.
Step 3: Eliminate choices that create new errors.
Step 4: Apply formal written English rules, not spoken patterns.
Step 5: Reread for clarity and correctness.

content.title: Apply the Strategy
content.question: Which choice correctly completes the sentence? 'The committee members, who were eager to finish the project, ____ working late into the night.'
content.explanation: 'Members' is plural → requires 'were'. Trap A ('was') and C ('is') mismatch in number/tense. Trap D ('has been') is wrong tense.

content.title: Solution Walkthrough
solution_steps: Verb must agree with plural subject.
Check D: 'has been' = singular and wrong tense.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.summary: Standard English Conventions test the mechanics of formal written English.
key_points: Watch out for run-ons, fragments, and comma misuse.
Always default to formal written rules, not spoken style.
content.next_steps: Practice with error-spotting drills for speed and accuracy.
